content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Reaction 1: <math alttext="C u O solid reacts to produce C u solid plus one half O 2 gas, where delta G naught equals 155 kilojoules per mole of reaction"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>155</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

A chemist wants to produce <math alttext="C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from a sample of pure <math alttext="C u O solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> according to reaction 1, represented by the equation above.

(a) Using the data in the following table, calculate the value of the standard entropy change, <math alttext="delta S naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction.

Substance
 Absolute Entropy at<math alttext="298 K, in joules per Kelvin per mole"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>298 K (J</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 33

<math alttext="O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 205

<math alttext="C u O solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 43

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Reaction 1: <math alttext="C u O solid reacts to produce C u solid plus one half O 2 gas, where delta G naught equals 155 kilojoules per mole of reaction"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>155</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

A chemist wants to produce <math alttext="C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from a sample of pure <math alttext="C u O solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> according to reaction 1, represented by the equation above.

(a) Using the data in the following table, calculate the value of the standard entropy change, <math alttext="delta S naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction.

Substance
 Absolute Entropy at<math alttext="298 K, in joules per Kelvin per mole"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>298 K (J</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 33

<math alttext="O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 205

<math alttext="C u O solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 43

(b) Given that <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for reaction 1 is positive <math alttext="155 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mn>155</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, what must be true about the sign of <math alttext="delta H naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction? Justify your answer.

The decomposition of <math alttext="C u O solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> into <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is not a thermodynamically favored reaction. However, to produce <math alttext="C u solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from <math alttext="C u O solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, the chemist decides to pass <math alttext="H 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> gas over the <math alttext="C u O solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> as it is heated strongly, as represented below.

Reaction 2: <math alttext="C u O solid plus H 2 gas react when heated to produce C u solid plus H 2 O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuO(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mover accent="true"><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><mstyle><mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></mover><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) Is reaction 2 an oxidation-reduction reaction? Justify your answer using oxidation numbers.

A third chemical reaction is represented below.

Reaction 3: <math alttext="H 2 gas plus one half O 2 gas react to produce H 2 O gas, where delta G naught equals negative 229 kilojoules per mole of reaction"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>229</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(d) Show how a combination of reaction 1 and reaction 3 can be used to produce reaction 2.

(e) Determine the value of <math alttext="delta G naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for reaction 2.

The chemist takes the <math alttext="C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced from reaction 2 and uses it to make an electrode in a galvanic cell, as shown in the following diagram.

(f) Using the reduction half-reactions in the table below, write a balanced net-ionic equation representing the overall reaction that takes place as the cell operates.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (volts)

<math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 electrons produce C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 0.337

<math alttext="Ag with a positive one charge aqueous plus one electron produce A g solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Ag(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 0.800
(g) Determine the value of <math alttext="E naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the cell.
(h) Determine the value of <math alttext="delta G naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the cell reaction.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
